Comments_List: I learned a lot about philosophy and how to formulate philosophical arguments. I had never taken a philosophy class before, so it was a learning experience. Very little focus on bioethics and more on theory, which I wasn't expecting. It was a whole new way of thinking, so the material was an uphill battle.

I learned a lot of philosophical arguments that are surprisingly applicable in modern debates about biology and bioethics. I found myself pondering them often outside of class and with friends and they really are interesting topics that dont have easy answers.
I gained an understanding of some of the philosophical traditions within the bioeethics field.
I got a lot better at thinking through moral philosophy problems.
I learned how to write a philosophy paper and discussed pressing issues in bioethics.
better knowledge of philosophical systems of morality and how they translate into practice
LOVED LATHAM
I learned a few new frames of philosophical argument and strategies to apply them to various bioethical and legal issues.
This class put a lot of names and information to issues that are all around us. The issues Professor Latham chose are very applicable and relatable, and help you think about the ethical implications.

I learned how to make concrete philosophical arguments about certain issues. With the help of other philosophers' thoughts, I was able to figure out how to talk about/defend my stance on bioethical issues such as abortion, physician-assisted suicide and surrogacy.

As someone with no philosophy experience at all before this class, I feel well equipped to take on bioethical questions with confidence. Great introduction to ethics. Very fun scenarios to wrestle with.

This was the first philosophy course I've taken and it gave me a really good basic understanding of how philosophy works and how to write a philosophy-style paper (a lot of this is attributable to my amazing Teaching Fellow, Kate). The course also helped me really deepen my understanding of specific issues in the field of bioethics.

I learned to think about different bioethical issues, such as abortion and physician assisted suicide, in new and different ways. I'm now familiar with various authors and philosophers' perspectives and how to apply them to different  problems.
Basics of philosophical argument.
I learned about philosophical questions that happened to apply to bioethics problems.
I learned so much in this course about philosophical arguments applied to bioethics issues. It was a mind-opening experience to ponder moral dilemmas and to consider multiple sides to the situation.
Philosophical concepts concerning bioethics topics
Interesting use of ethics to grapple with new kinds of biotechnology
General knowledge of bioethical issues, recognition of different argument structures and types in the sphere of applied ethics

I gained skills of philosophical thinking. I had previously taken Bioethics and Law with Latham, which was a more straightforward, apply-law-to-the-facts class. This class required philosophical argumentation and rhetorical skills that made the tests a bit difficult and hard to study for, but useful and beneficial overall

The class mainly focuses on philosophical ideas, which caught me off guard based on the title. I did build my knowledge and understanding of philosophy, and particularly how to structure a philosophical argument. The reading rarely focused on Bioethcis, which was fine, just not what I was expecting. But you will learn a lot about philosophy, and how to apply philosophical concepts to modern medical and biomedical issues.

By taking this class in succession with Bioethics and Law, I was able to understand very important bioethical issues from another perspective. Looking at controversial topics from a philosophical standpoint made me question why I had some of the legal stances that I had, and I often found that some of my stances were hard to back by philosophy.

This course provided the only real hard, critical thinking I did all semester, so for that I am grateful. It helped me really re-evaluate some previously held stances on biomedical and bioethical issues and examine the moral foundations upon which those stances rested. I enjoyed the lectures a lot, and I feel like Cr/D made it even more enjoyable because it allowed me to engage on a simply abstract level that took away the pressure and left room simply for intellectual growth. Latham is way better than Kagan, who almost scared me off of philosophy forever after Intro to Ethics.
Critical thinking, writing well-structured essays within timed parameters, engaging with material from many viewpoints
I learned a lot of basic ethical arguments and how they could be applied to medical questions.
How to argue in a rigorous way with special focus on topics in bioethics and medicine
I learned how controversial subjects are thought about from very different perspectives and how to argue something which has no true right answer.
Good overview and intro to bioethics
I learned about the philosophy of scientific issues.
I gained an in-depth understanding of various philosophical principles and arguments.  I developed an ability to apply these concepts to a plethora of bioethical issues.
how to critically analyze an argument and argue my point of view using the class readings
I learned different opinions and arguments regarding ethical dilemmas in the realm of bioethics.
The class explored many different topics in bioethics and also beyond, focusing more on philosophy rather than law.

Bioethics was my first ethics/philosophy class and it really broadened my mind and helped me to develop critical thinking skills. The class introduced me to controversial topics in bioethics, which give me a chance to challenge my core beliefs. Most importantly, it taught me that sharing my opinions is not enough, but that I should argue in a logical way so that others can see my viewpoint clearly.
I learned a lot about how ethics plays a role in the medical realm.

I learned a lot about how to separate a complex bioethics argument into its core claims, and the current state of affairs in ethics regarding the key issues that can be applied to bioethics (animal/non-human rights, trolley problem-related questions, etc.). I didn't learn as much about how to actually argue these issues effectively as I would have liked.
To become more inquisitive and learn to form my own arguments about large bioethical issues
How to over explain simple things.

The class was a mess. Latham's lecture would completely contradict the readings, and the lectures were very hard to follow. I wish he had slides. The readings were also long, boring, and dense. It was hard to discern what was important! I think uploading relevant readings and not just "UN declaration of human rights" or "catholic views on vaccines" would help. We hardly even discussed that! Clearly outlining what the topic of the week was, who the important people are, and how to apply the topic is crucial. Too many weeks I didn't know what was going on and I never missed a lecture. Make it more clear, concise, and focused.

Strengths: The class is interesting to those who are enjoy thinking about the philosophical issues within bioethics.
Weaknesses: The readings are not fully developed and severely lacking in other parts. In addition, there needs to be more structure to the lectures.

This course has interesting material, but I disliked the emphasis it placed on philosophy. I think that this class would be better as a writing class that discussed issues in bioethics without writing philosophical-style arguments. I also hated that there were timed exams to answer prompts. I don't understand why exams would ever be a good assessment of a class of this nature.

I appreciate how this course has a low barrier to entry, with regards to understanding some key philosophers' works. 

However, lecture is much less important than section, most notably because the recounting and reviewing of each work is more accurate, there.

The lectures were always very interesting as Professor Latham took you through a lot of thought experiments and possible scenarios that make you question what you originally thought, but the second class of the week was always pretty repetitive. He would generally talk about the same issues, just rephrased. That said, the class is still very interesting and the topics are ripe for two days worth of thought. It would be nice if there was something included in the final grade other than three large assignments, i.e. participation, reading responses, etc.

The lectures were mostly well-organized and demonstrated clear methodological concepts. However, some lectures seemed a bit off-topic or unnecessary. Instead of devoting 2+ lectures to every topic, the course could have included more philosophical concepts.
Incredible professor. Great material. Good readings. Though sometimes the readings can be a little dry...

Strengths: the professor and my TF were both fantastic. Unlike some professors, who would assign 400 pages of reading for a topic that could be covered in 10, Prof. Latham assigned a perfect amount of reading for us to learn about each subject, and his lectures were a great supplement to the material. Weaknesses: I really liked that our TA had us do weekly responses because they helped me clarify my opinions and solidify my understanding, and I think all future sections would benefit from similar assignments, but I think the course needs to have a participation grade. Even if small, it would make the contributions of students to section each week feel a little bit more meaningful and also make grades less intimidating (50% of our grade as the final exam = eek!). Also: in my section, we would often break into small groups to discuss different topics. I thought this format was so effective and so much less intimidating than other sections where I heard it was entirely seminar-style with everyone having to debate philosophy in front of the large group (which ends up being much less of a learning experience and much more of a stressful and performative one).

This was my favorite class this semester. I was always excited to go to lecture and I think Prof Latham was very engaging and presented different issues in an interesting way. My only complaint would be that grades were based on 3 assignments/exams, the final being worth 50%, so there were not many opportunities to adjust your grade.

Some weaknesses of the course: a relatively low level of effort on the part of the instructors. Latham is amazing, but his lectures were a little drier than Bioethics & Law and very little effort was put in over Canvas or anything like that. The TAs varied WIDELY as well; some TAs gave a lot more measured, thoughtful feedback to their students and were instrumental in developing good ways of thinking about the readings (this is feedback from acquaintances in other sections). Some TAs, however, ran a less helpful section and provided less feedback/response. This will have a big impact on your class experience, choose wisely. 
Strengths: Like I said, Latham's lectures are always fairly engaging. He clearly knows the material well and presents it well. It was also nice to get acquainted with some of the more iconic philosophy thought problems.
Strengths: amazing professor, engaging lectures, intriguing topics, very interesting readings, intellectually engaging
Strength: Profession Latham is INCREDIBLE. I LOVE his lectures and how he engages students discussion and inspire us to critically think about the issues
More time for tests, especially the midterm. It was a crunch
I think the class was organized well, and the workload was very manageable. There are no glaring weaknesses, although there are no obvious strengths either. It's a very typical lecture course.
I think the course is fine the way it is. Section was absolutely necessary, the tests were straightforward, and the material was a fair amount.
Great reading that is immediately relevant to the course material! Excellent lecture and discussion in section.
More structured readings and resources for essay writing would help. The content was fascinating but we were examined most stonglybon our essay writing skills rather than understanding
The readings are good and the lectures explain them well, but it might be good to have a way of holding us accountable for learning the material week by week, such as quizzes or homework assignments.
Great class. No complaints.
loved the course
The course was very interesting and Prof. Latham is a great lecturer.
I think there was a bit too much redundancy with cases. I felt it could be better organized. As it turns out there aren't that many different bioethics cases we needed to deal with
This course is structured very well.
The course was very interesting but slightly repetitive. Many of the arguments and topics are very sumilar.
The lectures were interesting, yet I felt like the material could have been organized better in order for students to understand what were the main concepts.

I liked that it was two lectures a week, which was not demanding of my time. The topics discussed in class were very interesting, and I liked how the course was organized so that each week was a new mode of argumentation. Having a discussion section allowed me to explore the topics in-depth within a smaller group, which I really appreciated.
This course was taught very well.

Strengths:
I liked the organization of the course - grouping by argument was a clever way to keep everything coherent as opposed to covering 6 different abortion arguments, then re-covering some of those arguments the next week for a different topic, etc.

Weaknesses:
This course needs more work. There were some weeks where we had one or two short readings that were supposed to cover a giant topic in the philosophy of ethics; more material would've helped me get more out of those weeks. Also the application of some areas of ethics to bioethics could have been made more explicit (e.g. rights)

The best part of the course was the section--I was happy to have a chance to talk about controversial issues in bioethics with students who are willing to listen to different viewpoints on issues such as abortion, surrogacy, etc.

Strengths: 50 min lectures, feedback
Weaknesses: everything else, besides feedback
Great credit/d course

Steer clear!! If you loved Bioethics and Law and think this class will be the same, it's NOT. The material is so complicated and it's organized poorly. The readings regularly contradict/don't relate to the lectures, and the lectures are so disorganized that I hardly know what's going on. It's sad because I love Latham, but this class was a constant headache. Be ready to camp out in office hours, especially if you're not a philosophy major, because it's hardly clear what the material or the point of the class is. The breakdown is midterm, final, and 5-7 page philosophy paper, but he's so disorganized you hardly have any time to do anything. Run away!

Professor Latham is a great professor and the topics covered in the course are all quite interesting. It's not a ton of work, but this was one of the first classes I actually enjoyed (or at least didn't mind) going to section because the discussions were stimulating and worthwhile. There's a decent amount of overlap with Bioethics and Law, but more of a philosophical approach
I really enjoyed Issues in Bioethics! Professor Latham is an extremely engaging lecturer and did a great job covering all of the topics in class, making the course a great learning experience.

I would recommend this course to someone who wants an easier course since there is not much work here but the intellectual challenge is also lacking. The readings are often subpar and section can be dependent on who is your TF.
Really fun and really easy. Learned interesting, relevant stuff about bioethics and also got better at moral phil. reasoning in general.
Maybe, because the workload was quite light and the material was interesting.

Absolutely! But beware, if you are expecting it to be like Bioethics and Law, and to lean on the political science side, it is pretty philosophy-heavy, and some people seemed unpleasantly surprised by this. If you do not enjoy thinking and writing philosophically, it probably isn't the class for you, or you at least should not expect it to be a walk in the park if you don't have some experience with philosophy.

Take it if you need to fulfill the political philosophy subfield in the Political Science department, but are scared that philosophy is too hard. Moral Foundations of Politics is a "better" class, but Issues in Bioethics is easier. 

This class might get a bad rep when compared to Latham's Bioethics and Law. That is definitely better, because Latham wasn't very accurate in Issues in Bioethics lectures, when considering how important the readings were in doing well on exams and papers. You do the real learning in section if you have any trouble.

The paper was easy. The midterm and final felt very much like Latham in that they were open-ended and probably not that difficult to do well if you put in the behind-the-scenes time.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who is remotely interested in bioethics. I feel like I learned a lot about how philosophical arguments can be formed, and also about how they can be used for practical, everyday situations.
Yes, definitely! This course really makes you think about the types of arguments used in common bioethical dilemmas and forces you to engage with them in a stimulating and interesting way!
This class is an absolute gem. One of my favorite ever at Yale. Probably the only class I have ever taken where every single lecture flew by without me knowing. I wish I could take it again.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Great professor and engaging lectures, light workload with reading assignments that are actually genuinely interesting, really fascinating topics and a great way to dip your toes into philosophy and philosophical thinking without having to jump into the dumb DS Western Cannon stuff. The philosophy in this class is contemporary and extremely relevant/applicable which made it much more interesting (in my opinion).

I would not recommend this class. Latham never prepares for lecture, usually arrives late, and rambles for 50 mins. For instance, hell explain the concept of exploitation in a long-winded fashion for 5 mins, then spend 45 mins applying that definition to different examples. The worst part of the lectures was when he would seem to have run out of things to say and he would ask the lecture hall What do you think?...

I'd recommend this course because it changed my way of thinking and I now feel more equipped to engage in common bioethical debates and better understand all sides and insights. I always left lecture wanting to discuss that day's topic with my friends.

If you've never taken a philosophy course before, I would recommend this for you. You get to learn all about different types of philosophical argument from a bioethics standpoint. Most of the things we discussed in section were based on arguments you've probably heard before (abortion, CRISPR gene editing, etc. with foundations in classic philosophical argument), so you could go into this class having only skimmed the readings just fine. The readings were interesting, though the intellectual challenge of this course wasn't very high.

I'd say consider what you'd like to get out of this class before taking. I went into this after Bioethics & Law, and was expecting/anticipating quite extensive bioethics material. However, this is MUCH more a philosophy class than a poli-sci class. There are occasional mentions of it but honestly this feels like a philosophy class that happens to have bioethics underpinnings--we could occasionally spend an entire lecture talking about a philosophical concept without its actual application to bioethics. So if you're a philosophy person, go for it; if you're looking for bioethics-centric, stick with Bioethics & Law in the spring.

Yes definitely! If you've taken Bioethics and law, this is a wonderful follow up where you will discuss the philosophy and morals of similar topics. Even if you haven't, this course will cause you to question your views and consider multiple perspectives. It will challenge your thinking and reasoning, very intellectually engaging! There was a midterm (2 short essays), a short 5-7 paper, and a final. A decent amount of readings but very interesting!
YES. Mind blowing!

This was a fantastic class that was very fun and engaging. It had a very low workload (a midterm, paper and final) but they weren't very long at all. Interesting material was covered and professor Latham was great.
Yes! Professor Latham is incredible!
I would recommend this course to another student. Good, interesting lectures, and good for developing skills of philosophical argumentation

It's a fine fifth class, but put in the effort to shop different TAs. As others will have likely said, working with Samantha was an unsatisfactory experience and I wouldn't say she helped our section better grasp the material.

If you like philosophy this is would be a good class to take! If you don't like philosophy, this class is not for you. The class is structured around philosophical topics, with new one each week. Lectures are spent loosely applying these questions to issues in bioethics, but the majority of the class focuses on philosophy in general. I had no major problems with the class, I just don't enjoy philosophical arguments so it wasn't my favorite. It makes a good fifth class though because it's easy to do well with minimal effort.

Any course by Professor Latham is one I will recommend. He is incredibly engaging and he makes going to lecture fun. If you took Bioethics and Law, definitely take this as well. Challenging some of your legal stances with philosophy is very engaging and will make you think critically. Generally an easy course if you pay attention and engage, but also one that you will get a lot out of. Take it!!
I would absolutely recommend it, particularly as a fifth class for a Cr/D. It engaged in some hot topics which made the class interesting at every turn.

Definitely take Issues in Bioethics! You do not need to have taken Bioethics and Law to understand the course, though if you enjoyed it, this is a great counterpart. One of the most thought-provoking classes at Yale.
Yes absolutely! Great compliment to Bioethics and Law.
Yes. It isn't too much work but the material is interesting and important.
Yes, Professor Latham is one of, if not the, best lecturers Ive had at Yale. I would say most of my learning came from attending lecture, which seems oddly rare for most lecture courses.
Yes it will open your mind to all the problems humans face and make you ask yourself where your own beliefs come from.
this class is fantastic
Yes it is a worthwhile class.
Yes, I would most certainly recommend this course to other students, regardless of major. The material learned is valuable to all.
Yes. This is an incredible class that is very intellectually stimulating and very pertinent to modern medical issues. Great 5th class for pre-meds
Take this class! Professor Latham is a great lecturer and the topics are always interesting.

This was a fantastic fifth class in my schedule. The lectures and the lecture topics were really fascinating. It was my first philosophy class ever and I enjoyed realizing how applicable ethical philosophy is to everyday life.
The class has a midterm, a short paper, and a final. The midterm and final were structured the same, and if you went to lecture, did the readings, and went to section, you were totally fine, and I actually enjoyed taking them. The short paper was not hard at all.
Yes.

This is an excellent course! I did not take Bioethics and Law, but I understood that many STEM students would take it as a social science credit. I think that this course is actually better designed for that role, or for anyone who is not distinctly interested in the relation between law and ethics. This class is an introduction to basic topics in philosophy -- the trolley problem, slippery slope arguments, etc -- that are then applied to bioethics cases. I thought it was a fascinating, and not difficult class and highly recommend it.
The course was super interesting, and not that much work. There really aren't any other courses on bioethics, so if you won't be put off by the lack of depth in some areas then sure take the course.
yea
